Basics.name: Jordan M. Duran
Basics.summary: I am a Ph.D. Candidate in Organizational Science at UNC Charlotte. My research focuses on the intersection of emerging technologies and organzing, especially related to issues of ethics, identity, and membership.

publications.name: Labor in Fissured Workplaces: Contract Workersâ€™ Membership Negotiation in Big Tech.
publications.summary: Big Tech companies increasingly use contract workers for key roles, enhancing their careers but limiting their influence and inclusion within the organization. Analysis of 500 crowdsourced reviews reveals these workers struggle with membership negotiation, impacting their ability to fully integrate and influence organizational processes.

publications.name: Electronic Communication
publications.summary: Electronic communication, encompassing email, social media, and artificial intelligence, profoundly impacts individuals, their relationships, personal identity, group affiliation, and community functioning. As new communication technologies continue to emerge, it is crucial for social psychologists to study the positive and negative effects of electronic communication on people.

publications.name: The discursive construction of risk in gig work
publications.summary: The gig economy has disrupted traditional working arrangements by introducing independent, hyper-flexible, short-term jobs with few worker-organization communication channels, leading gig workers to rely on virtual communities for shared interpretations and coping strategies due to limited face-to-face interactions. This chapter examines the unique risk-related dynamics of the gig economy, proposes a new theoretical framework, and suggests directions for future research on occupational safety and virtual communities in this context.
